channel.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
channel.description:
Title, 317 revision. Maybe some of the older members can explain this.
Edit:
Follow up question, how do they sort the HTTP like request from the normal binary formatted requests?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

No its not world one. This goes back to RSC days but they had a custom file serving server for all of their games this includes some of the really old one like vertigo they all used the so called “jaggrab” format which was an alternative to the HTTP get I’ve actually posted a working jaggrab server before but god know where the files are anymore.

Read full topic
item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:1, topic:542420”]Title, 317 revision. Maybe some of the older members can explain this.

Edit:

Follow up question, how do they sort the HTTP like request from the normal binary formatted requests?[/quote]
I guess this is what you were referring to?

private void closeRequest(OnDemandData onDemandData) { try { if(socket == null) { long l = System.currentTimeMillis(); if(l - openSocketTime < 4000L) return; openSocketTime = l; socket = clientInstance.openSocket(43594 + client.portOff); inputStream = socket.getInputStream(); outputStream = socket.getOutputStream(); outputStream.write(15); for(int j = 0; j < 8; j++) inputStream.read(); 
			loopCycle = 0;
		}
		ioBuffer[0] = (byte)onDemandData.dataType;
		ioBuffer[1] = (byte)(onDemandData.ID >> 8);
		ioBuffer[2] = (byte)onDemandData.ID;
		if(onDemandData.incomplete)
			ioBuffer[3] = 2;
		else
		if(!clientInstance.loggedIn)
			ioBuffer[3] = 1;
		else
			ioBuffer[3] = 0;
		outputStream.write(ioBuffer, 0, 4);
		writeLoopCycle = 0;
		failCounter = -10000;
		return;
	}
	catch(IOException ioexception) { }
	try
	{
		socket.close();
	}
	catch(Exception _ex) { }
	socket = null;
	inputStream = null;
	outputStream = null;
	expectedSize = 0;
	failCounter++;
}</blockquote>
private void login(String s, String s1, boolean flag) { signlink.errorname = s; try { writeSettings(); if(!flag) { loginMessage1 = ""; loginMessage2 = "Connecting to server..."; drawLoginScreen(true); } socketStream = new RSSocket(this, openSocket(43594 + portOff)); long l = TextClass.longForName(s); int i = (int)(l >> 16 & 31L); stream.currentOffset = 0; stream.writeWordBigEndian(14);//signal to client you want to login? stream.writeWordBigEndian(i); socketStream.queueBytes(2, stream.buffer); for(int j = 0; j < 8; j++) socketStream.read();
The green is what interests me. Both of them have a few similarities too?

Read full topic

item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

sinisoul:

It’s also important to note that Jagex reserves a packet for JAGGRAB in the future (id: 16) possibly to move away from some hackery that they had to do to differentiate a JAGGRAB request from a normal game server protocol packet.

Maybe I misunderstood, but id 16 is for login (while 18 is if the client tries to connect again).

Ashi:

What it could be is a “Master Server”, which the client initially connects too. Then it finds which world to direct the client to and passes that back to the client, and then client connects to the world.

There’s nothing in the code to suggest that.

Just have different port offsets for different worlds that run on the same machine. Recall how world selection used to work.

Read full topic
item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:16, topic:542420”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=661297.msg4421029#msg4421029 date=1398433852]

Read the thread.

My bad

@iKilem
portoff was for servers on the same IP running on a diff port I think
[/quote]

Well that’s pretty easily deduced. I don’t see why they would have a single machine running a single game server.[/quote]
What it could be is a “Master Server”, which the client initially connects too. Then it finds which world to direct the client to and passes that back to the client, and then client connects to the world.

item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:13, topic:542420”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=661297.msg4421008#msg4421008 date=1398424996]
You have a list of old parameters for that? If that’s the case: TIL. Then, what would the purpose of port 43595 be? Just to host an external JAGGRAB away from the web service?
[/quote]
All I have is the client. If it helps, the HTML parameter is called “portoff”. It’s also mentioned in the usage string (port-offset):

I’m not really sure what the purpose is. That’s where the older members come in I guess :P.[/quote]

So it’s possible that the JAGGRAB request is sent to a the game server, although possibly unlikely. Silab, Lothy, other nerds, come help and drop some knowledge on this.

Edit: That is if port-offset was equal to 1, which I honestly though the port-offset was just another name for the world id. It’s also important to note that Jagex reserves a packet for JAGGRAB in the future (id: 16) possibly to move away from some hackery that they had to do to differentiate a JAGGRAB request from a normal game server protocol packet.

Ashi:

The client will first try to connect to the server using port 80. If it’s successful, the client will then process requests using the HTTP protocol. If the HTTP service is unavailable, it will then connect to the server on port 43595, and requests will be made using the JAGGRAB protocol.

Read the thread.

Read full topic

All I have is the client. If it helps, the HTML parameter is called “portoff”. It’s also mentioned in the usage string (port-offset):

I’m not really sure what the purpose is. That’s where the older members come in I guess :P.

@Ashi wrote:

The client will first try to connect to the server using port 80. If it’s successful, the client will then process requests using the HTTP protocol. If the HTTP service is unavailable, it will then connect to the server on port 43595, and requests will be made using the JAGGRAB protocol.

item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:10, topic:542420”]aSocket832 = method19(43595);
How is 43595 game world 1 when this bit of code doesn’t depend on the world number?

The login method you posted has nothing to do with JAGGRAB and that “worldOff” variable has nothing to do with the world number. It’s a separate argument you pass in the command line.

Edit: Ok, so you thought they’d be on the same port if it was world 1. But yeah, “worldOff” isn’t the world number.[/quote]

You have a list of old parameters for that? If that’s the case: TIL. Then, what would the purpose of port 43595 be? Just to host an external JAGGRAB away from the web service?

Read full topic
item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

How is 43595 game world 1 when this bit of code doesn't depend on the world number?

The login method you posted has nothing to do with JAGGRAB and that "worldOff" variable has nothing to do with the world number. It's a separate argument you pass in the command line.

Edit: Ok, so you thought they'd be on the same port if it was world 1. But yeah, "worldOff" isn't the world number.

How is 43595 game world 1 when this bit of code doesn’t depend on the world number?

The login method you posted has nothing to do with JAGGRAB and that “worldOff” variable has nothing to do with the world number. It’s a separate argument you pass in the command line.

Edit: Ok, so you thought they’d be on the same port if it was world 1. But yeah, “worldOff” isn’t the world number.

item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:8, topic:542420”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=661297.msg4421001#msg4421001 date=1398422478]
No, I’m saying if web server request fails then it uses the game server. Which is where the question originates.
[/quote]
It doesn’t from what I can tell.

public final DataInputStream method132(String s)
    throws IOException
{
    if(!aBoolean872)
        if(signlink.mainapp != null)
            return signlink.openurl(s);
        else
            return new DataInputStream((new URL(getCodeBase(), s)).openStream());
    if(aSocket832 != null)
    {
        try
        {
            aSocket832.close();
        }
        catch(Exception _ex) { }
        aSocket832 = null;
    }
    aSocket832 = method19(43595);
    aSocket832.setSoTimeout(10000);
    java.io.InputStream inputstream = aSocket832.getInputStream();
    OutputStream outputstream = aSocket832.getOutputStream();
    outputstream.write(("JAGGRAB /" + s + "\n\n").getBytes());
    return new DataInputStream(inputstream);
}

If the request fails, aBoolean872 is negated, so it switches between the two servers.[/quote]

This is the piece I’m talking about. 43595 is game world 1.

    aSocket832 = method19(43595); 
    aSocket832.setSoTimeout(10000);
    java.io.InputStream inputstream = aSocket832.getInputStream();
    OutputStream outputstream = aSocket832.getOutputStream();
    outputstream.write(("JAGGRAB /" + s + "\n\n").getBytes());
    return new DataInputStream(inputstream);
private void login(String s, String s1, boolean flag) {
        Signlink.errorname = s;
        try {
            if (!flag) {
                loginMessage1 = "";
                loginMessage2 = "Connecting to server...";
                drawLoginScreen(true);
            }
            socketStream = new RSSocket(this, openSocket(43594 + worldOff));

Read full topic
item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

sinisoul:

No, I’m saying if web server request fails then it uses the game server. Which is where the question originates.

It doesn’t from what I can tell.

public final DataInputStream method132(String s)
    throws IOException
{
    if(!aBoolean872)
        if(signlink.mainapp != null)
            return signlink.openurl(s);
        else
            return new DataInputStream((new URL(getCodeBase(), s)).openStream());
    if(aSocket832 != null)
    {
        try
        {
            aSocket832.close();
        }
        catch(Exception _ex) { }
        aSocket832 = null;
    }
    aSocket832 = method19(43595);
    aSocket832.setSoTimeout(10000);
    java.io.InputStream inputstream = aSocket832.getInputStream();
    OutputStream outputstream = aSocket832.getOutputStream();
    outputstream.write(("JAGGRAB /" + s + "\n\n").getBytes());
    return new DataInputStream(inputstream);
}

If the request fails, aBoolean872 is negated, so it switches between the two servers.

Read full topic
item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini

@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“iKilem, post:6, topic:542420”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=661297.msg4420972#msg4420972 date=1398387241]
43595 is world 1
[/quote]
You’re saying only world 1 listened on port 43595 while the others used a http server?[/quote]

No, I’m saying if web server request fails then it uses the game server. Which is where the question originates.

item.source: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?

item.title: Why are JAGGRAB requests and normal server requests on the same port?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

iKilem:

They aren’t. The client will try to connect to the http server (port 80) to fetch the files. If that fails, it switches to port 43595 (and if that fails, it switches back, and so on). For “on demand” files, it uses the game port 43594, and those requests aren’t JAGGRAB.

43595 is world 1

Read full topic
